content.description: Start left of the first bolt, maybe clipping it with a single locker, then angle up right through the roof.  After gaining the ledge, head up left, following bolts.  After pulling the small roof, follow a neat finger crack and face ot the anchors.  Mostly good rock, maybe a section of barely questionable holds.
content.protection: 7 bolts, 1 pin, 2 bolt anchor.  Also take a #4 Camalot or tech Friend to back up the pin.  Rap or lower.
content.location: On the left side of Walrus Ledge.  This is the bolt line left of the dihedral crack system, Pressing Shish.  Start under a roof 10-15 feet off the ground.

content.description: Pull through the wide roof crack at the bottom, gaining a ledge.  The PG rating is for here because of the poor quality of rock.  After the ledge, follow the enjoyable hand/finger crack up to the anchor.  There is good rock on all but the starting roof.
content.protection: Gear to 2 or 3".  A wide cam for the start may be useful.  2 bolt anchor on the left or top out.
content.location: This is the dihedral crack on the left side of Walrus Ledge.  The start is under a wide roof crack.

content.description: Pull the very low roof to gain a ledge.  Some consider this part runout, because if you fall off the ledge or the first move without clipping, you will deck.  Continue up on vertical face climbing, joining Droopy Corndog up high.  Anchors are on a nice comfy ledge at the top, so you can walk off or rap in from here.  Good rock.
content.protection: Bolts, two bolt anchor over the top.  Rap, lower, or walk off.
content.location: On the left side of Walrus Ledge, this is the second bolt line right of the corner system on the left.  Starts at a very low roof with a bolt clippable from the ground.

content.description: Start in kind of a shallow corner, heading up and right.  Gains a small ledge, then up on face climbing and through a small roof, ending on a slab.  Anchors are on a ledge at the very top, allowing one to walk off or rap in.
content.protection: Bolts, two bolt anchor on a ledge at the top.  Lower, rap, or walk off.
content.location: On the left side of Walrus Ledge.  This is the first bolt line right of the dihedral crack system.

content.description:
11d/12a (see below) 

  Starts on a slightly overhung face/corner, climbing up into the layback face with the small ledge for feet.  Pull a bulge and climb the steep slab through a slightly chossy section and a scary-to-clip bolt.  Make a hard undercling move to jug pockets.  Steep pockets and sidepulls take you to thin moves at the top. 

  Holds have fallen off this route over the years.  Stay left at the 4th bolt, as some huge stuff has fallen off there.   

  Also, the top seems to be missing a hold, but it still goes.  This move and the undercling move below seem a bit easier for taller folks, leading me to suggest 11d/12a, as the crux move felt just as hard as Warrior Poet and Atmosfear (5'9").
content.location: Near the right end of Walrus Ledge, this is the first bolt line left of the large dihedral crack.

content.description: Between Black Snake Area and Weenie Buttress.
